questions.question: What is the overall shape of the displacement-time graph for vertical projectile motion?
questions.explanation: The vertical displacement follows the quadratic equation s = ut - ½gt², which is a parabolic relationship.

questions.question: What does the steep upward slope at the start represent?
options: The initial high velocity of the object moving upward
questions.explanation: A steeper slope means greater velocity; at t = 0, the object is thrown with its maximum speed.

questions.question: What happens to the velocity at the highest point of the curve?
options: The velocity is half the initial velocity
questions.explanation: The object stops moving upward before starting to fall downward — this is the turning point where kinetic energy is momentarily zero.

questions.question: Is the time taken to rise equal to the time to fall?
options: Yes, in a vacuum (no air resistance)
It depends on the initial velocity
questions.explanation: The motion is symmetric — same acceleration g acts downward both ways, so ascent and descent times are equal.

questions.question: How is the slope of the graph related to velocity?
questions.explanation: Since displacement-time graphs have slope = change in displacement ÷ change in time, a positive slope means upward motion and a negative slope means downward motion.

questions.question: What does the horizontal line represent?
questions.explanation: A horizontal line in a velocity-time graph represents uniform or constant velocity, hence the object is moving uniformly at 6m/s without acceleration.

questions.question: Why does the graph flatten at the top?
questions.explanation: The slope of the displacement-time graph becomes horizontal when velocity is zero — the object is momentarily at rest at maximum height.

questions.question: What does the downward-sloping portion represent?
options: The falling motion of the object back toward the ground
questions.explanation: The negative slope indicates decreasing displacement — the object is moving downward with increasing speed.

questions.question: What is the total time of flight for an object thrown up at 20 m/s? (g = 9.8 m/s²)
questions.explanation: Time to rise = u/g = 2.04 s, and the total flight time is twice that because ascent = descent: 2 × 2.04 = 4.08 s

questions.question: What is the maximum height reached by an object thrown upward at 20 m/s? (g = 9.8 m/s²)
questions.explanation: At the top, velocity = 0, so using v² = u² - 2gh, we get h = u²/2g = (20)²/(2 × 9.8) = 400/19.6 ≈ 20.4 m

questions.question: At what point is the acceleration of the object greatest?
questions.explanation: Gravity provides constant acceleration of 9.8 m/s² downward throughout the entire motion.

questions.question: What is the velocity of the object when it returns to its starting point?
options: Equal to the initial velocity but downward
questions.explanation: Due to symmetry, the object returns with the same speed as it was thrown, but in the opposite direction.

questions.question: How does air resistance affect the motion shown in the graph?
options: It makes the ascent time shorter than descent time
It makes the descent time shorter than ascent time
questions.explanation: Air resistance reduces the maximum height and makes the ascent time shorter than descent time, breaking the perfect symmetry.

questions.question: What is the displacement when the object returns to its starting point?
questions.explanation: Displacement is measured from the starting point, so when the object returns, its displacement is zero.

questions.question: During which part of the motion is the velocity positive?
questions.explanation: Velocity is positive (upward) during ascent and negative (downward) during descent.

questions.question: What is the acceleration at the highest point?
questions.explanation: Even though velocity is zero at the highest point, acceleration due to gravity remains constant at 9.8 m/s² downward.

questions.question: How would the graph change if the object were thrown with greater initial velocity?
options: The parabola would be wider and taller
The shape would change to a straight line
questions.explanation: Greater initial velocity increases both the maximum height and total time of flight, making the parabola wider and taller.

questions.question: What is the speed of the object halfway up during ascent?
options: Less than initial speed but greater than zero
questions.explanation: The object slows down continuously during ascent, so at halfway up, its speed is less than initial speed but still positive.

questions.question: Conceptual: Why is projectile motion analysis important in physics?
options: It demonstrates fundamental principles of kinematics and gravity
It's only useful for sports applications
It applies only to objects thrown vertically
It's a theoretical concept with no real applications
questions.explanation: Projectile motion demonstrates key physics principles including constant acceleration, energy conservation, and the independence of horizontal and vertical motions.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered vertical projectile motion analysis!
scoreMessages.70: Strong work! You understand the key concepts of projectile motion but should review the symmetry properties.
scoreMessages.50: Good progress! Focus on understanding the parabolic nature of projectile motion and the constant acceleration due to gravity.
scoreMessages.0: Review the fundamental concepts: displacement follows a parabola, velocity is zero at the peak, and acceleration is constant downward.
